prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Track 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Cores in IRDCs A, B, C, E: A1, A2, A3, B1, B2, C2, C3, C4, C5, C6, C7, C8, C9, E1, E2

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The requested line sensitivity is 2 times worse than our Cycle 0 N2D+ observation where we had 15 sigma detection of integrated intensity in the cores. However, we estimate N2D+/N2H+ ~ 0.1 from modeling and observation. So N2H+ SNR achieved in this proposal should be even better. N2D+/N2H+ = 0.1 is already a large value in astrochemistry study, the actually ratio could be smaller, meaning N2H+(3-2) could be even stronger (see science case). The line width from Cycle 0 observation is ~ 1 km/s for N2D+, however we expect N2H+ have slightly broader linewidth. The chosen velocity resolution is able to resolve the spectra well.
We want to use the best resolution available, but we can smooth to 0.16 km/s which can still resolve the spectra with ~ 1.2 km/s width well.

The cores detected in our Cycle 0 observation have angular size 3-7 arcsec. The desired resolution can resolve the cores well. But since our goal is mainly deuteration in the cores and kinematics, we could sacrifice a little angular resolution if needed. Also this angular resolution can be done with C36-2 C36-3 configuration, thus avoiding daytime observation of some of the sources.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Track 2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Cores in IRDCs D, F, G, H: D1, D2/D4, D3, D5/D7, D6, D8, D9, F3, F4, H1, H2, H3, H4, H5, H6

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The requested line sensitivity is 2 times worse than our Cycle 0 N2D+ observation where we had 15 sigma detection of integrated intensity in the cores. However, we estimate N2D+/N2H+ ~ 0.1 from modeling and observation. So N2H+ SNR achieved in this proposal should be even better. N2D+/N2H+ = 0.1 is already a large value in astrochemistry study, the actually ratio could be smaller, meaning N2H+(3-2) could be even stronger (see science case). The line width from Cycle 0 observation is ~ 1 km/s for N2D+, however we expect N2H+ have slightly broader linewidth. The chosen velocity resolution is able to resolve the spectra well.
We want to use the best resolution available, but we can smooth to 0.16 km/s which can still resolve the spectra with ~ 1.2 km/s width well.

The cores detected in our Cycle 0 observation have angular size 3-7 arcsec. The desired resolution can resolve the cores well. But since our goal is mainly deuteration in the cores and kinematics, we could sacrifice a little angular resolution if needed. Also this angular resolution can be done with C36-2 C36-3 configuration, thus avoiding daytime observation of some of the sources.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Track 3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Cores in IRDCs C, F, G: C1-N, C1-S, F1, F2, G2-N, G2-S

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The requested line sensitivity is 2 times worse than our Cycle 0 N2D+ observation where we had 15 sigma detection of integrated intensity in the cores. However, we estimate N2D+/N2H+ ~ 0.1 from modeling and observation. So N2H+ SNR achieved in this proposal should be even better. N2D+/N2H+ = 0.1 is already a large value in astrochemistry study, the actually ratio could be smaller, meaning N2H+(3-2) could be even stronger (see science case). The line width from Cycle 0 observation is ~ 1 km/s for N2D+, however we expect N2H+ have slightly broader linewidth. The chosen velocity resolution is able to resolve the spectra well.
We want to use the best resolution available, but we can smooth to 0.16 km/s which can still resolve the spectra with ~ 1.2 km/s width well.

The cores detected in our Cycle 0 observation have angular size 3-7 arcsec. The desired resolution can resolve the cores well. But since our goal is mainly deuteration in the cores and kinematics, we could sacrifice a little angular resolution if needed. Also this angular resolution can be done with C36-2 C36-3 configuration, thus avoiding daytime observation of some of the sources.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We have observed N2D+(3-2) line emission with ALMA in Cycles 0 and 2 in ~40 IRDC clumps in order to search for massive starless cores, which may be the initial conditions of massive star formation. Here we propose to efficiently measure the level of deuterium fractionation in these regions by observing N2H+(3-2) line emission, a method which yields estimates that are relatively insensitive to excitation temperature uncertainties. By comparing with already developed astrochemical models of the deuteration process, we will be able to constrain the chemical (deuteration) age of the cores, and thus infer the dynamical history of the cores. This information, which will be avaialbe for a large sample of cores, will further refine theoretical models of massive star formation.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy, Florida, University of

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy, Florida, University of
